description.narrative: The Australian Awards Pacific Scholarships (AAPS)is a multi-country initiative that provides access for developing country nationals to tertiary education in Pacific institutions every year. Study areas are based on respective Pacific countries Government's priority areas as well as those of the Australian Aid program. In many of these countries there are no universities located within country and this program forms an important part of each country's overall tertiary training needs. Previous scholars now hold important roles in government and industry. The program collaborates closely with the New Zealand program as well as the respective Pacific Islands Government's own scholarships program. The total value of this initiative for all Pacific countries is $38.6 million over 10 years, starting 2009-10.

The Nauru Public Sector Reform Partnership will support implementation of Government of Nauru strategies for public sector reform, improved economic governance and financial management, with an emphasis on: strengthening the capacity of central agencies to deliver and manage national budgets that are aligned with national development policies and plans; developing and implementing policies that reduce fiscal risks and improve revenue generation, including from state-owned enterprises (SOEs); improving communication between the Government of Nauru and the community on policy development and implementation progress; and improving collection and management of development statistics, to inform policy and measure progress against key development outcomes.

Australia's bilateral aid to the Republic of Palau focuses on the following three strategic objectives: 1. Reducing the threats from explosive remnants of war. Palau was a major battlefield in World War II and the vast amounts of unexploded bombs, mines and artillery shells have been a danger to people and a hindrance to effective land use and development. 2. Achieving greater gender quality and enhancing women's empowerment 3. Co-finance with the World Bank a project that will reform the ICT sector as part of a wider project to lay a new submarine cable that will provide more stable and faster access to the internet for the government, private sector, NGOs, schools and individuals. Australian assistance will focus on providing technical assistance to improve the ICT policy and regulatory environment. Advances in the ICT sector will provide a more enabling environment for the country's development.

Insecurity is an impediment to Afghanistan's development and security costs comprising the single largest share of Afghanistan's budget. In 2012, Australia and the international community made a commitment to assist Afghanistan in financing its security costs for the period 2015 to 2020. Australia's annual US$100 million 'Chicago' commitment is split between the Department of Defence for the NATO Afghan National Army and Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) for the Afghan National Police (ANP). In 2015, DFAT directed its support for the ANP through the Law and Order Trust Fund for Afghanistan (LOTFA), managed by the United Nations Development Programme. In conjunction with the Afghan Ministries of Finance and Internal Affairs, LOTFA administers the payment of police salaries under a broader program of police professionalisation and institutional reform. The total value of this investment is $185.5 million over 5 years, starting 2015-16.

title.narrative: Leveraging Australian expertise to improve learning outcomes in the Indo-Pacific

description.narrative: Australia is a world leader in education delivery, assessment and research. This investment aims to leverage Australian resources and expertise to improve learning outcomes in the Indo-Pacific through access to education resources, knowledge and evidence and learning assessment tools. Activities are responsive to the education challenges of our region including COVID-19 response efforts. A key activity, Australia's partnership with the Australian Council for Educational Research’s (ACER) Centre for Global Education Monitoring (GEM) provides countries with an opportunity to access technical expertise to improve education assessment in our region. Funding under this investment also enables Australian technical input (and representation of regional interests) to global discussion on education, including in the context of the Sustainable Develpment Goals.

Kiribati faces a number of development challenges including: highest number (68%) of Violence Against Women cases out of 9 other Pacific countries conducting the same study; 70% of Tuberculosis cases are in South Tarawa; increases in infant mortality rate as a result of pneumonia, diarrhoea and malnutrition; South Tarawa suffers from severe overcrowding. The Aid Investment Priority and Aid Partnership Arrangement aims to address these issues through delivering assistance that focuses on reducing the spread of communicable diseases, youth crime; alcohol consumption and domestic violence. The Kiribati Health program is identified as a key priority under new Aid Investment Plan (AIP) and Aid Partnership Arrangement and will support ongoing strategic support to the health sector in addressing high burden communicable diseases (tuberculosis, leprosy and Hepatitis B), health system strengthening and preparing and responding to health threats. The World Health Organization's Contingency Fund for Emergencies (CFE) was established in 2015 following a review of the 2014 Ebola outbreak response. Contributions, are mainly used to enable the immediate mobilisation of expert WHO personnel in response to disease outbreaks. In 2017, the CFE enabled 36 outbreak response operations at a cost of US$20.8 million across 23 countries including Madagascar (plague), the Democratic Republic of the Congo (Ebola), Bangladesh (water-borne and vaccine-preventable diseases affecting Rohingya refugees), Fiji and Vanuatu (health emergencies arising from natural disasters). The CFE has proven to be a very effective tool for outbreak containment, as was demonstrated most notably in the case of the previous Ebola outbreak in Likati, DRC, in mid-2017. The proposed contribution of up to $4 million by Australia would position us as the fourth largest donor to the CFE in cumulative terms after Germany, the UK and Japan. Health is an important priority to both Vanuatu and Australia in the National Sustainable Development Plan (NSDP) and the Australia-Vanuatu Aid Partnership Arrangement 2016-19. The investment is designed as a long term fifteen year program. This is the first three year phase. The goal of this investment is for effective delivery of the health components of the NSDP and commitment to health services demanded at national, provincial and local levels by a healthy, secure and productive population. The program has two equally important and mutually reinforcing end of program outcomes : I. Ministry of Health senior staff lead continuous improvement and strengthened accountability of the Vanuatu health sector II. Ministry of Health corporate services, public health and clinic services staff increase delivery of equitable, accessible and better quality essential health services. The total value of this investment is $15 million to be expensed over 3 financial years starting in 2019-20.

Building on Australia's long-standing support to Indonesia on health security, the new Australia-Indonesia Health Security Partnership (AIHSP) will continue to help strengthen Indonesia's ability to mitigate, detect and respond to health emergencies and reduce the threat posed by emerging infectious diseases. It will facilitate better access to senior levels within Indonesian government agencies, particularly in the event of an emerging infestiouc disease threat and to support Indonesia to better equip itself to detect and control pandemic threats to the region, including to Australia and Australians.

Program aims to build new and strengthen existing partnerships between Pacific and Australian church leaders; and enhance the leadership and capacity of Pacific and Australian church leaders to address common develpment challenges. Church leaders' capacities will be supported in identified areas of mutual priority including: Ending Violence Against Women, youth empowerment, the advancement of human rights and financial and business management. The total estimated value of this investment is $2.1 million over five years from April 2019 to 30 June 2023.

description.narrative: Expenses incurred during the financial year 2019/20 for Investments with a start date on or after 1 July 2008

RIDI aims to contribute to inclusive economic growth in the Philippines and achievement of the Philippines development objectives by supporting evidence-based policy and program implementation and by strengthening policy eco-systems. Key thematic areas of focus are: supporting inclusive economic growth; promoting evidence-based policy development; and understanding demographics for policy development. The investment will consolidate initiatives by continuing our engagement with AdRI (currently residual agreements under the now cancelled Trade Facility (INL799)), and two of our key research partnerships, currently under the Research Initiative (INJ168) (a longitudinal study with UNFPA and our partnership with 3ie on impact assessments). The design will also consider other research activities that contribute to the objectives of this investment and Australia’s broader policy interests.

description.narrative: Expenses incurred during the financial year 2019/20 for Investments with a start date on or after 1 July 2008

The Papua New Guinea (PNG) Food Futures Initiative supports a number of rural development activities in agriculture and food security. It includes a broad spectrum of activities aimed at connecting smallholder farmers to markets and creating more efficient agricultural value chains. Activities include support to women in agriculture, digital agriculture solutions, data collection and policy support and capacity building, agricultural education in schools, nutrition, and horticulture, poultry and aquaculture value chain development. The initiative partners with a range of Papua New Guinean, Australian and International organisations and personnel. Given the impact of Covid-19 in Papua New Guinea, activities under the initiative have been adapted to focus even more on food security and economic recovery. The total estimated value of this investment is $7.0 million to be expensed over 4 years, starting during the 2019-20 financial year.

Fundung under this initiative provides assistance to support Samoa's Health Sector to respond to the meassles outbreak (October to December). In addition, activities under the initiative have been adapted to support Samoa's preparations and response to the current health pandemic. Specifically the initiative will provide surge capacity through Emergency Medical Teams for the measles outbreak, public health and clinical advisers to support the transition to recovery phase and public health support for Samoa's preparations for COVID-19 and also to support renovations for isolation wards.

title.narrative: Humanitarian Support for Flood Response in Dili, Timor-Leste

description.narrative: Based on a request from the Government of Timor-Leste, this investment will provide humanitarian support to people affected by the flood that hit Dili on 13 March 2020. The support will be delivered through the Australian Humanitarian Partnership (which includes CARE, Caritas, Oxfam, Plan and World Vision). The support will include relief supplies, reconstruction materials, clean water, sanitation and hygiene and public health messaging on COVID-19. The total value of the investment is $500,000 over six months, starting in 2020.

description.narrative: Expenses incurred during the financial year 2019/20 for Investments with a start date on or after 1 July 2008

title.narrative: Reducing the Risk of Corona Virus (COVID - 19) in Bangladesh

description.narrative: The Coronavirus (COVID-19) was declared a pandemic by the Director-General of WHO on 13 March 2020. Global predictions are that the next epicentre of Coronavirus will be the Indian sub-continent, and 30 crore people will be infected. Health specialists think with non-profits joining the government paralleled in reaching its aim of containing the virus will limit the impact on the population. As the disease spreads, there is need for testing facilities to be decentralised. The shortage of food is already being felt in the urban markets. Price of daily necessities is increasing. Poor people are losing their work and earning as daily necessities are not being supplied as before, and people's mobility has halted. DFAT will support and respond to COVID-19 through BRAC by: - Food support for the to 27,000 people through 6,500 households; and - Risk communication and public awareness of COVID-19 reaching at least 5 million households

title.narrative: COVID-19 Pacific Support Package: economic and health impact funding

description.narrative: A grant financing package to support Timor-Leste and Pacific Island Countries’ (PNG, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Fiji, Nauru, Tonga, Tuvalu, Samoa, Kiribati ) response to COVID-19. The package will bolster funds across three key areas: 1) support for direct outbreak preparedness and response 2) support for broader health institutions and systems 3) support for broader economic impacts and recovery. It will use a range of existing country and multi-country mechanisms including budget support to assist in maintaining liquidity, and funding to plan and maintain key services as the virus hits. The total estimated value of this investment is $100.0 million to be expensed during the 2019-20 financial year.

The Myanmar Health and Development Consortium (MHDC) is a locally registered NGO and trusted partner who is supporting MOHS in their COVID-19 response. title.narrative: Support to Bangladesh for COVID-19 Preparedness and Response

description.narrative: The World Food Program (WFP) will utilise this emergency support from Australia to work with the Bangladesh Government to ensure food security for Bangladeshis currently in Covid-19 quarantine in either government or private facilities across the country. WFP will also assist Bangladesh Government procure protective and healthcare equipment for treatment, and equipment to assist build testing capabilities. The emergency support through this investment is aligned with the United Nations and Bangladesh Government's Country Preparedness and Response Plan (CPRP). The total estimated value of this investment is $2.0 million to be expensed during the 2019-20 financial year.

title.narrative: Solomon Islands Disaster Management and Climate Resilience

description.narrative: The Solomon Islands Disaster Management and Climate Resilience investment will: 1) Support the Solomon Islands Government to ensure the National Disaster Management Office (NDMO) and provincial authorities are capable of preparing for and responding to disasters and COVID-19. 2) Strengthen the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) to provide sustained technical disaster preparedness and response support to Solomon Islands 3) Increase climate and disaster resilience in select communities, including in Malaita province The investment will also support disaster response and assistance, replenishing NFI stocks, contributions to ADF HADR exercises in Solomon Islands, humanitarian logistics support and similar activities. The total estimated value of this investment is $2.9 million over 2 years, commencing in the 2019-20 financial year.

title.narrative: Humanitarian and Health COVID-19 Response in Laos

description.narrative: Australian Humanitarian and Health COVID-19 Response in Laos Investment is to support the Lao Government's COVID -19 economic, humanitarian and health response. This support includes 1) support to PSI for COVID preparednes/EOC training; 2) technical assistance for Lao PDR Competitiveness and Trade (LCT) project for Laos's economy recovery; 3)technical assitance and capacity development to support Human Rights in response to COVID; 4) support to UN partners (UNICEF, WHO, and UNFPA) focusing on health, nutrition, education and protection; and 5) support to AHP for early recovery following COVID outbreak focusing on health, nutrition, education, and livelihood. description.narrative: Expenses incurred during the financial year 2019/20 for Investments with a start date on or after 1 July 2008

WFP is appealing for funds under the Pacific Humanitarian Team COVID-19 Response Plan, including on food security. COVID-19 is exacerbating food insecurity in the Pacific through supply chain disruptions and the impact of government imposed movement restrictions. A first order priority is to understand the food security and economic impacts of the COVID-19 crisis. Australia is funding WFP AUD 1 million to rollout rapid food security assessments across the Pacific, including Fiji, Vanuatu, Solomon Islands, Tonga and Samoa, followed by Kiribati and Tuvalu. We will also earmark AUD 1.5 million to support WFP’s operations in Myanmar, a priority country under the Global COVID-19 Humanitarian Response Plan. Funds will help WFP provide life-saving assistance to those whose access to livelihood opportunities have been dramatically curtailed by movement restrictions imposed due to COVID-19. The total estimated value of this investment is AUD 2.5 million to be expensed in 2019-20 FY.

We will also earmark AUD 1.5 million to support WFP’s operations in Myanmar, a priority country under the Global COVID-19 Humanitarian Response Plan. Funds will help WFP provide life-saving assistance to those whose access to livelihood opportunities have been dramatically curtailed by movement restrictions imposed due to COVID-19. The total estimated value of this investment is AUD 2.5 million to be expensed in 2019-20 FY.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Pacific and Timor-Leste Preparedness and Recovery NGO Partnership

description.narrative: This investment will provide funding to non-government organisations (NGOs) to support communities in the Pacific and Timor-Leste to prepare for, respond to and recover from COVID-19. It will provide multi-sectoral, flexible support, tailored to individual country contexts. It will include support to health services and hygiene promotion, water and sanitation facilities, social protection measures and gender-based violence support services. It will use existing NGO funding mechanisms, focused on countries with the highest absorptive capacity and need (including Timor-Leste, PNG, Solomon Islands, Fiji and Vanuatu). It will build on already existing NGO support in target countries and include specific activities focused on gender, disability inclusion and protection. Between 2 and 5 per cent of the investment will be allocated to monitoring and evaluation. The total estimated value is $25 million, to be expensed during the 2019-20 financial year.

title.narrative: Covid-19 Response for Vulnerable Children and Youth in Bangladesh

description.narrative: The NGO UCEP is currently implementing DFAT’s Skills for Economic Growth investment (INN116) in Bangladesh. A large number of UCEP’s currently enrolled underprivileged children and youth are directly impacted as a result of COVID-19. This new investment is linked to INN116 and will directly benefit UCEP’s current beneficiaries, which in turn will mitigate the risks of DFAT’s ongoing investment by ensuring students’ safe return to schools and technical institutes, and preventing child labour, early child marriages, and other negative secondary impacts of the COVID crisis in Bangladesh. The children and youth require attention, counselling and motivation to continue with virtual education sessions –the most marginalized can only participate when their families meet the basic daily necessities. Families of 3,217 underprivileged students (girls, Persons with Disabilities, ethnic community beneficiaries) will be covered under this assistance program (i.e. basic food/cash support )

Funding under this investment will support UNHCR's COVID-19 preparedness and response operations in the Indo-Pacific. It will allow UNHCR to continue to protect the most vulnerable in our region from the direct and indirect impacts of COVID-19, and to scale-up lifesaving protection and assistance activities in Bangladesh and Myanmar. The total value of this investment is $2.5 million, 2019-20.

description.narrative: Expenses incurred during the financial year 2019/20 for Investments with a start date on or after 1 July 2008

In Mongolia, children are experiencing restrictions as a result of COVID-19 since the end of January 2020. These restrictions mean no school, no meetups with friends, limited recreation activities and the inability of children to access safe spaces for support. Together with other stress factors such as parents losing income and jobs, children’s mental health issues, tension in families and domestic violence have sharply increased over the last few months. The investment will: • Consultations with children and adolescents to ensure their perspectives and needs are incorporated to help to better target responses. • Disseminate information that is timely, factual, contextually appropriate, accurately translated and accessible to all. • Train personnel including child protection and development staff, and better detect violence against children for provision of child protection.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response 2nd Activation in Fiji AHP (FJI-0018)

description.narrative: This activation will assist people living in rural, semi-urban and urban locations who have been economically and socially affected by COVID19, especially women, youth and adolescents, people with disabilities and LGBTIQ+ to establish sustainable and diverse livelihoods and meet their protection needs. This will be achieved by delivering a suite of interventions, based on assessments and analysis, such as capacity building, provision of resources, technical advice, demonstrations, access to longer term financial support, social services like counselling, and ongoing mentoring.

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

description.narrative: COVID19 pandemic and lockdowns that followed have disproportionately hurt marginalized communities due to loss of livelihood and lack of access to food, shelter, health, and other basic needs. This has choked off almost all-economic activities. Leading to the widespread loss of jobs and incomes for informal workers and the poor that in turn causes untold misery for them. Oxfam's COVID-19 responses look different in each country but activities may include a) food and nutrition security covering cooked meal, dry ration and self-help community kitchens, b) water, sanitation and health (WaSH) covering bathing soaps, sanitisers, masks, sanitary napkins, disinfectants, washing powder/detergent soaps etc. for the community, c) essential health supplies for service providers (PPE kits) -full body covers, disposable googles, aprons, N95 masks, surgical gloves in additional to alcohol based hand sanitiser, handwashing liquid soap etc, d) unconditional cash transfer (UCT) as a means to give flexibility to the beneficiaries for meeting other needs over ‘fixed package in-kind support’ and as a means to boost to the local economy, e) training/ orientation of the humanitarian staff, government frontline workers on COVID19 (through digitally available mediums and using context specific methodologies that addresses the concerns of Protection Protocols for COVID19) and f) communications/materials on COVID19 in local languages

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

description.narrative: This initiative run by Oxfam’s Global Humanitarian team seeks to support marginalized communities that have been disproportionately hurt by COVID-19 due to loss of livelihood and lack of access to food, shelter, health, and other basic needs. The project activities in different countries vary depending on the context, but may include a) Food and nutrition, b) Water, sanitation and health (WaSH), c) Essential health supplies for service providers, d) Unconditional cash transfer, d) Training of humanitarian staff and government frontline workers on COVID19 and f) Communications on COVID19 in local language

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

title.narrative: Anticipatory Response for South West Monsoon Flooding (LKA-0174)

description.narrative: The project is provides alternative shelter for vulnerable families that are likely to be affected by the South West Monsoon flodding, offering safe spaces for accommodation while simultaneously ensuring that potential risks of exposure to COVID 19 are mitigated through prevention and behaviour messaging. The project also provides mental and psychosocial support to the affected displaced persons particularly children who are already experiencing anxiety, stress and trauma to be exacerbated as the prolonged lockdown continues.

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

description.narrative: COVID19 pandemic and lockdowns that followed have disproportionately hurt marginalized communities due to loss of livelihood and lack of access to food, shelter, health, and other basic needs. This has choked off almost all-economic activities. Leading to the widespread loss of jobs and incomes for informal workers and the poor that in turn causes untold misery for them. Oxfam's COVID-19 responses look different in each country but activities may include a) food and nutrition security covering cooked meal, dry ration and self-help community kitchens, b) water, sanitation and health (WaSH) covering bathing soaps, sanitisers, masks, sanitary napkins, disinfectants, washing powder/detergent soaps etc. for the community, c) essential health supplies for service providers (PPE kits) -full body covers, disposable googles, aprons, N95 masks, surgical gloves in additional to alcohol based hand sanitiser, handwashing liquid soap etc, d) unconditional cash transfer (UCT) as a means to give flexibility to the beneficiaries for meeting other needs over ‘fixed package in-kind support’ and as a means to boost to the local economy, e) training/ orientation of the humanitarian staff, government frontline workers on COVID19 (through digitally available mediums and using context specific methodologies that addresses the concerns of Protection Protocols for COVID19) and f) communications/materials on COVID19 in local languages

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

description.narrative: This project aims to prepare vulnerable groups and rural communities in the Eastern Highlands and Simbu provinces of PNG to prevent and slow the potential spread of Covid-19 through increased awareness of and access to good hygiene practices, notably through dissemination of multi-media public health messaging and the design and installation of handwashing stations, with a focus on safe houses for women victims of sexual and gender-based violence.

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response 2nd Activation in PNG AHP (PNG-0059)

description.narrative: This project's overarching objective is to enhance the resilience of COVID-19 affected communities in PNG against future shocks such as a further spike in COVID-19. To do so, the consortium partners are focusing on the most pressing needs highlighted through recent assessments which have underlined the secondary impacts of the current crisis, demonstrating the core sectors which become impacted during a response such as COVID-19. This includes enhancing community access to appropriate WASH facilities, improving livelihoods initiatives, strengthening response mechanisms for survivors of gender-based violence (GBV) and other protection concerns, and improving disaster risk reduction (DRR) across provincial, district, and local actors. Given the disproportionate impact a humanitarian crisis has upon them and the limited engagement at decision making moments normally afforded, particular attention will be paid to vulnerable or marginalised community members, including women, girls, boys and those living with disabilities. Each NGO will partner with local implementing agents including disabled people and organisations (DPOs) to ensure that projects are designed, monitoring, and adapted based on the particular needs and perspectives of these groups.

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

title.narrative: AHP COVID-19 Response in Solomon Island (SLB-0044)

description.narrative: This proposal aims to strengthen and complement existing risk communication mechanism of the Government and AHP Consortia partners. This will include a) communication of COVID-19 safety messages, hygiene promotion and IEC materials using inclusive contextually and age-appropriate messages, c) strengthen communities existing Action Plans to integrate COVID-19 risk imperatives, c) capacity training of AHP Consortia partners including training on accessible communication, and d) WASH intervention through existing networks with emphasis on women. These activities will be implemented through community meetings and engagement where AHP NGOs are already active. Implementing partners will leverage local networks, undertaking awareness and training activities with community committees, schools, churches and other institutions.

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response 2nd Activation in Solomon Islands AHP (SLB-0045)

description.narrative: This response builds the resilience of targeted communities to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in terms of improved food security and livelihoods and access to water, sanitation and hygiene, while ensuring inclusion and protection of vulnerable groups and community capacity to manage COVID related and other risks. The program is implemented by a consortium of AHP agencies working with an extensive range of local actors including local government, the biggest church denominations and networks in the country, local non-government organisations, associations and committees representing target groups and community based organisations. The program builds upon the partners' extensive experience in disaster risk management in the targeted locations and sectors and the established consortium structure. The consortium ensures value for money through access to shared services, coordination and leveraging of the operational presence and current projects implemented by the partners including the DFAT funded regional Disaster READY Program and COVID-19 Pacific Preparedness project.

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

description.narrative: This project provides assistance to the Government of Timor-Leste's response to the Dili Flash Floods (13 March 2020) within a context of a growing international COVID 19 pandemic. AHP Agencies are working with the government to identify support areas based on vulnerability and needs assessment. Sectors proposed include distribution of non-food items, WASH, community health messaging (including on COVID 19) and construction support for damaged households, with a focus on affected vulnerable people (people with disabilities, older persons [60+], female single headed households and people pregnant and breasfeeding). This 6-month project will be implemented with other AHP Agencies based in Dili including CARE, Caritas Australia, Oxfam, Plan and World Vision who have been operating in Timor-Leste since 2000.

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response in Timor EU funds (TLS-0057)

description.narrative: The "COVID-19 Response in Timor-Leste" project aims to strengthen civil society capacity to improve the health and well-being of vulnerable groups at risk of being affect by COVI-19 in Timor-Leste. Implemented by a consortium with other NGOs including Care, Oxfam, Plan International, CRS and World Vision, the project outcomes are 1) The Timorese health sector is strengthened/supported through increased practice of handwashing and hygiene behaviours to prevent the spread of COVID-19 among targeted women, men, boys and girls, 2) The impact of the COVID-19 crisis' effect on the economy is mitigated through ensuring that targeted people, including those most vulnerable, are able to continue to buy, sell, produce and reach markets during the COVID-19 crisis, and 3) The social impacts on the population, especially the most vulnerable, are mitigated through increased awareness of gender-based violence services and promotion and support to referral services.

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response 2nd Activation in Timor AHP (TLS-0060)

description.narrative: In coalition with other INGO's including CARE Australia, Plan, Caritas, and World Vision, this responses focuses on livelihoods, food security, nutrition, health promotion, WASH and education to build community resilience to the effects of COVID-19.

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

description.narrative: This COVID-19 response seeks to contribute towards the development of high quality, inclusive, MoH approved communication packages, along with supporting local partners, community leaders and community stakeholders in disseminating risk communication packages, as well as fostering improved awareness within communities of key messages. In coalition with other INGO's this coordinated response seeks to ensure that the delivery of nationally endorsed preparedness and response risk communication is responsive to the unique contexts and challenges of communities. The response strategies will target both the general population while also ensuring that key audiences such as women, children, people with disabilities and people in high risk situations (people in urban centres, people sharing hygiene facilities, people continuing to engage in risky activities due to livelihood necessity), as well as immune suppressed and older people.

organisation.narrative: Oxfam Australia

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response 2nd Activation in Vanuatu AHP (VUT-0041)

description.narrative: The COVID-19 response is focused around improving purchasing power to enable vulnerable households to meet their basic needs, as well as leveraging the voucher-based local vendor network to boost market recovery. The response outcomes include 1) Increase access to livelihoods and basic needs for 3,700 TC Harold and COVID-19 affected households fulfilling vulnerability and targeting criteria generated by the Vulnerable Livelihoods and Income Impact Survey (ongoing), 2) Accelerate localized and participatory market recovery by increasing household purchasing power to nurture and increase revenue of informal/formal businesses in an localised and inclusive manner that ensures cash transfer funds continue to circulate at the community level, 3) Address existing capacity gaps of national partners and expand the scale of CVA implementation in Vanuatu, easy to use payments platform (UnBlocked Cash) to deliver and monitor programme implementation (vendor and recipient payments).

title.narrative: Formation initiale et perfectionnement des cadres de la Police Nationale d'Haiti
Initial Training and Professional Development for the Haitian National Police's Managerial Staff

description.narrative: Ce projet vise à contribuer à la professionnalisation de la Police Nationale d'Haiti (PNH) par la formation initiale et le perfectionnement des inspecteurs et des commissaires. Le projet appuie le développement d'un nouveau curriculum de formation, ainsi que le développement et la mise en place de la structure administrative et organisationnelle d'une institution de formation. Les activités du projet comprennent: 1) une assistance technique à la PNH pour l'élaboration et la mise en oeuvre de programmes de formation selon l'approche par compétences; 2) la formation des formateurs; 3) l'élaboration et la mise en oeuvre de la structure organisationnelle et administrative de l'Académie nationale de police et la prestation d'une formation en gestion; 4) la réhabilitation et l'aménagement de locaux temporaires pour la formation; 5) l'achat de matériel didactique et d'équipement. Les activités prévues face à la COVID-19 inclue, des activités de sensibilisation pour les populations adjacente à l’ANP pour limiter la propagation de la pandémie ; appuie de subsistance alimentaire pour les élèves ainsi que les employés de l’ANP, en plus de relayer la diffusion des communiqués et contenus (capsules audio et vidéo) du MSPP.

This project aims to enhance the professionalism of the Haitian National Police (HNP) through initial training and professional development for inspectors and commissioners. It supports the development of a new training curriculum and the development and implementation of the organizational and administrative structure for a training institution. Project activities include: (1) technical assistance to HNP for developing and implementing training programs using a skills-based approach; (2) train-the-trainer training; (3) development and implementation of the organizational and administrative structure for the National Police Academy and delivery of management training; (4) rehabilitation and preparation of temporary training premises; (5) purchase of educational material and equipment. Activities planned in response to COVID-19 include outreach activities for populations adjacent to the PNA to limit the spread of the pandemic; food subsistence support for students as well as PNA employees, in addition to relaying the dissemination of MSPP communiqués and content (audio and video capsules).

description.narrative: Parmi les résultats obtenus jusqu’en mars 2016 : 1) les infrastructures de l'Académie nationale de police possède des espaces de bureau qui accueillent l’administration de l’académie, des espaces de formation constitués de salles de classe et ateliers pouvant accueillir 48 apprenants et des espaces de dortoirs composés de dortoirs pour hommes et de dortoirs pour femmes; 2) les programmes de formation des commissaires et inspecteurs ont été conçus et approuvés par la Police nationale d’Haïti; 3) 19 professeurs dispensent des cours aux officiers en utilisant ces programmes et l’Académie nationale de police s’est dotée d’une structure organisationnelle de gestion qui est efficace; 4) huit programmes ont été entièrement développés et 326 nouveaux commissaires et inspecteurs, dont 27 femmes, ont été formés. Dix-neuf de ces dernières ont été formées depuis 2017; 5) la sixième année du projet a été marquée par l’élaboration et le début de la mise en œuvre du Plan stratégique 2015-2018 de l’ANP.

Results achieved as of March 2016 include: 1) infrastructure for the National Police Academy (ANP) has office space for the ANP administration, training areas with classrooms and work areas for 48 students as well as dormitories for men and women; 2) training programs for commissioners and inspectors have been prepared and approved by the ANP; 3) 19 instructors give courses to officers using the programs, and the ANP is managed through an effective organizational structure; 4) eight programs have been fully developed and 326 new commissioners and inspectors, including 27 women, have been trained. Nineteen of these have been trained since 2017; 5) the sixth year of the project was marked by the development and initial implementation of the ANP’s 2015-2018 strategic plan.

title.narrative: Entente de partenariat stratégique avec le BRAC (BRAC-SPA)

description.narrative: Ce projet vise à donner aux femmes et aux filles les plus défavorisées et privées de leurs droits au Bangladesh (y compris celles qui sont handicapées) un meilleur accès aux ressources et davantage de contrôle sur les décisions et les mesures qui ont un effet sur leur vie. Le projet compte différents volets conçus pour atteindre les objectifs suivants : 1) réduire l’extrême pauvreté; 2) accroître l’accès à des services essentiels de qualité pour les groupes les plus pauvres et marginalisés au Bangladesh; 3) créer des possibilités d’emploi pour les jeunes défavorisés, les personnes handicapées extrêmement pauvres et les migrants; 4) renforcer le pouvoir des femmes dans les sphères économique et sociale; 5) améliorer le statut des femmes et des filles et réduire la violence à leur égard; 6) améliorer la gestion de la COVID-19 par les communautés. Les activités de ce projet comprennent : 1) permettre à 6 650 ménages de sortir de l’extrême pauvreté en ayant des moyens de subsistance durables et une meilleure résilience socio-économique; 2) renforcer la résilience de 17 500 ménages vulnérables au climat; 3) fournir des services complets en matière de santé et de droits sexuels et reproductifs à 100 000 personnes; 4) aider 5 550 enfants (au moins 50 % de filles et 2 % de personnes handicapées) à terminer leur scolarité primaire avec de meilleures compétences; 5) former 1 360 personnes pour leur permettre d’acquérir des compétences recherchées sur le marché et pouvant leur donner accès à un travail décent; 6) fournir des services de conseil et d’aide juridique à 20 750 survivantes de violences faites aux femmes; 7) conscientiser plus d’un million de personnes pour les associer aux efforts visant à lutter contre la violence faite aux femmes et aux enfants et à prévenir les mariages d’enfants; 8) produire et distribuer des masques en tissu réutilisables parmi les personnes à faible revenu pour ralentir la transmission de la COVID-19; 9) renforcer les initiatives de protection de la santé en mobilisant et en informant la communauté pour assurer une meilleure gestion des cas, prévention des infections, réduction des risques et sensibilisation; 10) donner accès à des mécanismes de soutien des moyens de subsistance au cours de la reprise après la pandémie.

This project aims to empower the most underserved and disenfranchised women and girls in Bangladesh (including those with disabilities) to gain greater access to and control over resources, decisions and actions that affect their lives. The project components are designed to achieve the following goals: (1) lowering levels of extreme poverty; (2) increasing access to quality essential services for the poorest and most marginalized groups in Bangladesh; (3) creating employment opportunities for underprivileged youth, extremely poor disabled people and migrants; (4) increasing economic and social empowerment of women; (5) improving the status of women and girls and reduce violence against women girls; and (6) improving COVID-19 management by communities. Project activities include: (1) enabling 6,650 households to graduate from extreme poverty with better sustainable livelihoods and socioeconomic resilience; (2) strengthening the resilience of 17,500 climate vulnerable households; (3) providing comprehensive health and SRHR services to 100,000 people; (4) supporting 5,550 children (at least 50% girls and 2% with disabilities) to complete primary education with better learning competencies; (5) training 1,360 people with marketable skills linked to decent employment opportunities; (6) providing counseling and legal aid services to 20,750 women survivors of violence against women; (7) engaging with over 1 million people through awareness efforts on violence against women and children and prevention of child marriage; (8) producing and distributing reusable cloth masks among the low-income people to slow down community transmission of COVID-19; (9) improving protective health initiatives through community engagement and communication for better case management, infection prevention, risk reduction and awareness building; and (10) creating access to livelihood support mechanisms in post-pandemic recovery.

description.narrative: Les résultats escpmtés de ce projet comprennent : 1) une utilisation accrue des services essentiels (moyens de subsistance, finances, actifs, éducation, santé, eau et assainissement, et services d’aide juridique), en particulier par les femmes et les filles marginalisées dans les zones difficiles à atteindre; 2) l’amélioration des services et des mécanismes locaux (p. ex. juridiques, santé et droits sexuels et reproductifs, violence sexuelle et sexiste, mariages d’enfants) pour éliminer les contraintes pesant sur l’exercice de leurs droits par les femmes; 3) l’amélioration de la capacité du gouvernement national de mettre en œuvre efficacement des politiques visant à favoriser l’égalité des genres; 4) l’augmentation de l’adhésion de la communauté aux mesures de prévention de la COVID-19 et la diminution des effets de la COVID-19 dans les communautés.

The expected outcomes for this project include: (1) increased use of critical services (livelihood, finance, assets, education, health, water and sanitation, and legal aid services), especially by marginalized women and girls in hard to reach areas; (2) improved services and mechanisms (e.g. legal, SRHR, sexual and gender-based violence, and child marriage) at the local level to respond to gender-specific constraints on rights; (3) improved capacity of national government to effectively implement gender-responsive policies; and (4) increased community adherence to COVID-19 preventive measures and decreased effects of COVID-19 at the community levels.

title.narrative: Addressing Sexual and Gender-Based Violence Through Public Institutions
Répondre à la violence sexuelle et sexiste par l’entremise des Institutions publiques

description.narrative: Le projet vise à promouvoir l'égalité entre les sexes et les droits de la personne en faveur des femmes et des filles en renforçant la capacité du Sri Lanka à répondre à la violence sexuelle et sexiste, notamment dans le contexte de la pandémie de coronavirus (COVID-19). Il est conçu pour soutenir le Ministère des affaires féminines et de l'enfance, d'autres entités gouvernementales compétentes, la Commission nationale des droits de la personne et les organisations locales de défense des droits des femmes dans leur réponse à la violence sexuelle et sexiste. Il vise également à soutenir la mise en œuvre de politiques et stratégies liées à la violence sexuelle et sexiste, y compris le cadre politique et le plan d'action national de lutte contre la violence sexuelle et sexiste (2016-2020). Les activités de ce projet comprennent : 1) le lancement de la première enquête nationale pour recueillir des données sur la violence sexuelle et sexiste; 2) la formation des fonctionnaires du Ministère sri-lankais des affaires féminines et de l'enfance et d'autres entités gouvernementales compétentes pour comprendre et utiliser les données afin de générer des réponses factuelles à la violence sexuelle et sexiste; 3) la formation de la Commission nationale des droits de l'homme du Sri Lanka à comprendre la violence sexuelle et sexiste et le rôle qu'elle peut jouer dans la lutte contre la violence sexuelle et sexiste; 4) le renforcement les capacités du Ministère sri-lankais des affaires féminines et de l'enfance de suivre la mise en œuvre de certaines politiques et stratégies gouvernementales, en particulier le Cadre d'action et le Plan d' action national de lutte contre la violence sexuelle et sexiste; 5) le soutien à un engagement et une collaboration accrus entre le Ministère sri-lankais des affaires féminines et de l'enfance et les organisations locales de défense des droits des femmes afin de promouvoir l'égalité et l'autonomisation des femmes, 6) la lutte contre l’augmentation de la violence sexuelle et sexiste envers les groupes vulnerables en conséquence de la pandémie de COVID-19, grâce à l’appui aux hôpitaux, le conseil virtuel aux victimes de violence, et une campagne publiciatire dans le media (ce qui inclut le media sociale) contre le la violence sexuelle et sexiste.

The project aims to advance gender equality and the human rights of women and girls by strengthening Sri Lanka’s capacity to respond to sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV), including in the context of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. It is designed to support the Ministry of Women and Child Affairs, other relevant government entities, the National Human Rights Commission and local women’s rights organizations in their response to SGBV. It also seeks to support the implementation of SGBV-related policies and strategies, including the Policy Framework and National Plan of Action to Address SGBV (2016-2020). Activities include: (1) commissioning the first national-level survey to gather data on SGBV; (2) training officials from the Sri Lankan Ministry of Women and Child Affairs and other relevant government entities to understand and use data to generate evidence-based responses to SGBV; (3) training the Sri Lanka National Human Rights Commission to understand SGBV and the role it can play in addressing SGBV; (4) building the capacity of the Sri Lankan Ministry of Women and Child Affairs to monitor the implementation of selected government policies and strategies, particularly the Policy Framework and National Plan of Action to Address SGBV; (5) supporting increased engagement and collaboration between the Sri Lankan Ministry of Women and Child Affairs and local women’s rights organizations in order to advance women’s equality and empowerment; and 6) addressing the increased SGBV challenges for vulnerable populations due to the COVID-19 pandemic through support to hospitals, virtual counselling for victims of violence, and a media (including social media) campaign against SGBV.

description.narrative: Parmi les résultats obtenus jusqu'en (mars 2020) : 1) 279 fournisseurs de services en matière de lutte contre la violence sexuelle et fondée sur le genre ont été formés à une coordination efficace avec d’autres acteurs clés (comme les gouvernements et les services de police locaux); 2) l'achèvement de la collecte de données pour la première étude nationale de prévalence de la violence sexuelle et fondée sur le genre au Sri Lanka; 3) un système de collecte de données sur le Web a été mis en place pour aider à suivre les progrès du plan d’action national contre la violence sexuelle et fondée sur le genre.

Results achieved as of( March 2020) include: (1) trained 279 sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) service providers in effective coordination with other key actors (e.g. local governments and police); (2) completed data collection for the Sri Lanka’s first national SGBV prevalence study; and (3) established a web-based data collection system to help monitor progress on the SGBV National Action Plan.

Les résultats escomptés de ce projet comprennent : 1) une efficacité accrue du Ministère sri-lankais des affaires féminines et de l'enfance dans la lutte contre la violence sexuelle et sexiste; 2) le renforcement du suivi par le Ministère sri-lankais des affaires féminines et de l'enfance de la mise en œuvre de certaines politiques et stratégies gouvernementales, en particulier le Cadre d'action et le Plan d'action national de lutte contre la violence sexuelle et sexiste (2016-2020); 3) un engagement accru du Ministère sri-lankais des affaires féminines et de l'enfance auprès des organisations locales de défense des droits des femmes afin de promouvoir l'égalité et l'autonomisation des femmes.

The expected outcomes for this project include: (1) increased effectiveness of the Sri Lankan Ministry of Women and Child Affairs in addressing Sexual and Gender-Based Violence (SGBV); (2) strengthened monitoring by the Sri Lankan Ministry of Women and Child Affairs of the implementation of selected government policies and strategies, particularly the Policy Framework and National Plan of Action to Address SGBV (2016-2020); and (3) improved engagement of the Sri Lankan Ministry of Women and Child Affairs with local women’s rights organizations to advance women’s equality and empowerment.

title.narrative: Appui à la gouvernance locale inclusive en Haïti
Inclusive Local Governance Support in Haiti

description.narrative: Les activités de lutte contre la propagations de la COVID-19 prévues son de fournir des équipements de protection individuelle au personnel des administrations communales en vue d’assurer prestation des services des mairies ; fournir un appui en matériels de sensibilisation ; informer la population sur la présence et la propagation du Covid19, sur les mesures préventives et des comportements à tenir afin de prévenir la contamination communautaire. Le projet vise à renforcer la capacité des populations locales d’Haïti à participer au développement de leur communauté, de façon à ce que toutes les femmes et tous les hommes des communautés urbaines ou rurales, puissent bénéficier de services publics décents et d’opportunités économiques diversifiées. Les activités du projet comprennent : 1) appui et accompagnement de trois ministères et organisations impliqués dans la décentralisation : (ministère de la Planification et de la Coopération externe; ministère de l’Intérieur et des Collectivités territoriales et Office de Management des Ressources Humaines); 2) renforcement des capacités de pilotage de la décentralisation; 3) formation et mentorat auprès des femmes maires; 4) appui à des collectivités locales ciblées dans la mobilisation et la gestion des recettes fiscales; 5) organisation d’ateliers de consultation et de campagnes de sensibilisation pour une meilleure intégration des besoins et des préoccupations des femmes dans le développement local.

The activities to prevent the spread of COVID-19 includes providing personal protective equipment to the personnel of municipal administrations in order to ensure the provision of municipal services; providing support in the form of awareness-raising materials; informing the population about the presence and spread of Covid19 , preventive measures and behaviours to be followed in order to prevent community contamination. The project aims to build the capacity of Haiti’s local populations to participate in the development of their community so that all women and men in urban or rural communities benefit from decent public services and diversified economic opportunities. Project activities include the following: (1) supporting and assisting three ministries and organizations involved in the decentralization (Ministry of Planning and External Cooperation, Ministry of the Interior and Territorial Communities, and the Office of Human Resource Management); (2) building capacity for steering the decentralization; (3) training and mentoring women mayors; (4) supporting local communities targeted for revenue generation and management; and (5) organizing consultation workshops and awareness campaigns to better integrate the needs and concerns of women into local development.

The expected results for this project include the following: (1) decentralization and deconcentration efforts are conducted in a strategic, coordinated and inclusive manner, ensuring integration of the distinct perspectives and priorities of women; (2) territorial institutions are modernized and strengthened in order to leverage a more accountable and inclusive local governance that adequately responds to people’s needs; and (3) development of territories is driven and rebalanced by the use of tools and approaches that take into account local circumstances and women’s specific needs.

title.narrative: Partenariat pour l'éducation en soins infirmiers pédiatriques au Ghana

description.narrative: Ce projet vise à réduire le taux de mortalité et de maladie chez les nouveau-nés et les enfants des régions mal servies des districts du Ghana. En élargissant les programmes de soins infirmiers en pédiatrie, ce projet vise à développer les compétences professionnelles des infirmières en pédiatrie et des travailleurs de la santé, afin de permettre aux infirmières et aux sages-femmes de fournir aux nouveau-nés et aux enfants des soins de qualité, à la fois rentables et éprouvés. Ce projet fournit des fonds supplémentaires en réponse aux besoins immédiats de la pandémie COVID-19 pour améliorer l'accès à des soins de santé de qualité, renforcer l'éducation et la sensibilisation et démystifier les rumeurs sur COVID-19. Les activités de ce projet comprennent : (1) étendre la formation liée à COVID-19 dans tout le Ghana à tous les niveaux du système de santé; 2) améliorer les connaissances et les compétences des infirmièr(e)s et autres travailleurs de la santé dans la prestation des soins de santé pendant la pandémie COVID-19; 3) assurer que les travailleurs de la santé sont équipés et continuent à fournir des soins de santé routiniers aux enfants et aux familles de manière sûre; 4) diriger les activités de sensibilisation par les chefs des cliniques et les agents de changement, et les infirmières diplômées, qui ont la confiance de leurs communautés. Le projet escompte toucher directement par l’entremise de la formation environ 1 500 personnes, dont des infirmières, des sages-femmes et des travailleurs de la santé. Il est également escompté qu’environ 6 700 000 enfants et nouveau-nés bénéficieront de meilleurs services de santé suite à la mise à niveau des programmes de formation spécialisée de soins infirmiers en pédiatrie au Ghana. Les activités liées à COVID-19 devraient bénéficier directement à 86 660 personnes (dont 65 495 femmes) et indirectement à 3,6 millions de citoyens du Ghana grâce à la formation spécifique des travailleurs de la santé à COVID-19.

This project aims to reduce death and illness among newborns and children in underserved districts in Ghana. By expanding paediatric nurse programs, this project seeks to build the professional skills of paediatric nurses and health workers to provide quality, cost-effective, evidence-based nursing and midwifery care to newborns and children. This project is providing additional funds in response to the immediate needs of the COVID-19 pandemic for enhanced access to quality healthcare, strengthening education and awareness and demystifying rumours of COVID-19. Project activities include: (1) expanding COVID-19 related training across Ghana to all levels of the health system; 2) enhancing the knowledge and skills of nurses and other health workers in delivering health care during the COVID-19 pandemic; 3) ensuring health workers are equipped and continue to provide routine care to children and families in a safe manner; and 4) leading of outreach activities by clinical leaders and change agents, and graduate nurses, who are trusted in their communities. The project expects to reach about 1,500 people, including nurses, midwives and health workers, directly with training. Approximately 6,700,000 children and newborns are also expected to benefit from better health services as a result of the scale-up of paediatric nursing programs in Ghana. The COVID-19 related activities are expected to directly benefit 86,660 people (including 65,495 females) and indirectly benefit 3.6 million citizens of Ghana as a result of health care workers receiving and delivering COVID-19 specific training.

title.narrative: Développement du marché de l’assainissement et de l’hygiène en milieu rural au Nord du Ghana
Rural Sanitation and Hygiene Market Development in Northern Ghana

description.narrative: Ce projet vise à réduire le fardeau des maladies liées à l’assainissement dans le nord du Ghana en introduisant des innovations grandement nécessaires dans la chaîne d’approvisionnement du marché de l’assainissement et de l’hygiène pour améliorer la disponibilité et l’utilisation durable de solutions abordables et appropriées pour les ménages ghanéens. Ce projet continue à faire avancer les travaux des projets RuSHING précédemment financés, mais en mettant particulièrement l'accent sur les activités visant à limiter la propagation du coronavirus (COVID-19). Les activités du projet comprennent : 1) l'installation de 100 stations de lavage des mains dans des espaces publics stratégiques; 2) l'engagement de 100 moniteurs pour assurer la propreté de chaque station et sensibiliser les utilisateurs sur la façon dont COVID-19 se propage; 3) la diffusion de messages d'intérêt public sur 25 stations de radio dans les zones du projet. Ce projet vise à faciliter l'adoption de comportements d'assainissement et d'hygiène des mains améliorés pour les Ghanéens des zones rurales, qui n'ont pas accès à un assainissement amélioré dans leurs foyers. Ce projet vise également à développer un marché de l'assainissement en facilitant directement la conception, la production et la vente de toilettes dans les régions du nord du Ghana.

This project aims to reduce the burden of sanitation-related diseases in Northern Ghana, by introducing much-needed supply chain innovations to improve the availability, affordability and sustained use of appropriate sanitation and hygiene solutions for Ghanaian households. This project continues to advance the work of previously funded RuSHING projects, but with a particular focus on activities aimed at limiting the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19). Project activities include: (1) installing 100 hand-washing stations in strategic public spaces; (2) engaging 100 monitors to ensure cleanliness of each station and raise awareness of users on how COVID-19 spreads; and (3) broadcasting of public service announcements on 25 radio stations across project areas. This project seeks to facilitate the adoption of improved sanitation and hand hygiene behaviors for rural Ghanaians, who do not have access to improved sanitation in their homes. This project also works to develop a sanitation market through the direct facilitation of design, production, and sale of toilets across Ghana’s northern regions.

description.narrative: Les résultats escomptés de ce projet comprennent : 1) adoption accrue de bonnes pratiques d'assainissement et d'hygiène dans les communautés rurales des trois régions du nord du Ghana pour améliorer la santé, y compris la santé maternelle, néonatale et infantile; 2) capacité accrue des chaînes de valeur d'approvisionnement commercial à améliorer les résultats sanitaires par la prestation de services d'assainissement; 3) capacité accrue du gouvernement à soutenir des approches de l'assainissement fondées sur le marché, ce volet du projet étant particulièrement axé sur les résultats un et deux.

The expected outcomes for this project include: (1) increased adoption of good sanitation and hygiene practices in rural communities in Ghana’s three northern regions to improve health, including maternal, newborn and child health; (2) increased capacity of commercial supply value chains to improve health outcomes through delivery of sanitation services; and (3) increased government capacity to support market-based approaches to sanitation with this component of the project having a particular focus on outcomes one and two.

title.narrative: Appui au continuum santé mères-enfants - Réponse à la COVID-19
Supporting the Continuum of Care for Mothers and Children - COVID-19 response

description.narrative: Le projet appuie la mise en place de programmes de santé pour les mères, les nouveau-nés et les enfants, en collaboration avec le ministère de la Santé et la population locale, afin de contribuer à la réduction du nombre de décès chez les mères, les nouveau-nés et les enfants dans le nord du pays. Ce projet apporte des fonds supplémentaires en réponse aux besoins immédiats de réponse à la pandémie de coronavirus (COVID-19). Les activités de ce projet comprennent : 1) le soutien à la réalisation des fonctions essentielles de santé publique et au développement de stratégies innovantes d’adaptation des services; 2) l’appui à la mise en œuvre de la Prise en charge intégrée des maladies de l'enfant (PCIME), avec une focalisation sur la malnutrition touchant principalement les enfants; 3) le soutien à l’adaptation et au renforcement des activités de mobilisation sociale pour la santé, promotion de la santé, prévention auprès des populations, ainsi que des activités de prévention de la violence faite aux femmes/filles; 4) la formation et encadrement du personnel de prestations de services, personnel de soutien et appui à l’organisation et l’adaptation des services; 5) le soutien logistique. Le projet est mis en œuvre par un consortium composé de l’Université de Montréal, qui en assure la direction et du Centre d’étude et de coopération internationale.

The initiative supports the implementation of maternal, newborn and child health programs, contributing to the reduction in the number of maternal, newborn and child deaths in the country’s northern region by working with the Ministry of health and the local population. This project provides additional funds in response to immediate needs to respond to the coronavirus pandemic (COVID-19). Project activities include: 1) support for the achievement of essential public health functions and the development of innovative strategies for adapting services; 2) support for the implementation of Integrated Management of Childhood Illnesses (IMCI), with a focus on malnutrition mainly affecting children; 3) support for the adaptation and strengthening of social mobilization activities for health, health promotion, prevention among populations, as well as activities to prevent violence against women / girls; 4) training and supervision of service delivery staff, support staff and support for the organization and adaptation of services; and 5) logistical support. This initiative is implemented through a consortium led by the Université de Montréal, and including the Centre d'étude et de coopération internationale.

title.narrative: Canada-Africa Initiative to Address Maternal and Child Mortality - COVID-19 Response
L’initiative Canada-Afrique pour réduire la mortalité des mères et des enfants - Réponse au COVID-19

description.narrative: Ce projet vise à réduire la mortalité maternelle, néonatale et infantile dans certaines communautés en travaillant avec les autorités sanitaires locales, en soutenant l'utilisation de l'approche intégrée axée sur la santé, la nutrition, et l'eau, l'assainissement et l'hygiène. Ce projet fournit également des fonds supplémentaires en réponse aux besoins immédiats de la pandémie COVID-19 en formant et en soutenant les travailleurs de la santé, en diffusant des informations clés sur la santé et en déployant des fournitures, ainsi que des infrastructures simples, d'eau, d'assainissement et d'hygiène dans les communautés. Les activités du projet comprennent: 1) déployer la technologie mobile pour former et soutenir les travailleurs de la santé et les agents de santé communautaires conformément aux plans d'intervention du ministère de la santé; 2) élaborer et mettre en œuvre des stratégies d'engagement communautaire pour diffuser des informations essentielles sur la santé, ainsi que du matériel d'éducation et de communication; 3) déployer des fournitures, des infrastructures simples et des interventions d'eau, d'assainissement et d'hygiène au niveau communautaire. Ce project compte bénéficier directement à 947 922 personnes (dont 481 622 femmes et filles), composées de travailleurs de la santé, d'agents de santé communautaires et d'autres agents communautaires.

This project aims to reduce maternal, neonatal and child mortality in select communities by working with local health authorities, and supporting the use of an integrated approach focused on health, nutrition, and water, sanitation and hygiene. The project also provides additional funds in response to the immediate needs of the COVID-19 pandemic by training and supporting health care workers, disseminating key health information, and deploying water, sanitation and hygiene supplies and simple infrastructure in communities. Project activities include: (1) deploying mobile technology to train and support healthcare workers and community health workers in line with Ministry of Health response plans; (2) developing and implementing community engagement strategies to disseminate key health information, education and communication materials; and (3) deploying rapid water, sanitation and hygiene supplies, simple infrastructure and responses at the community level. This project expects to directly benefit 947,922 people (of which 481,622 women and girls), comprised of health care workers, community health workers and other community agents.

Ce projet fournit également des fonds supplémentaires en réponse aux besoins immédiats de la pandémie COVID-19 en en formant et en soutenant les travailleurs de la santé, en atteindre les communautés sur des sujets de santé essentiels et en fournissant des provisions d'eau, d'assainissement et d'hygiène aux établissements de santé et aux communautés. Les activités du projet comprennent: 1) la formation et le soutien des travailleurs de la santé pour répondre à la COVID-19 et à la violence sexuelle et basée sur le genre; 2) élaborer et mettre en œuvre des stratégies d'engagement communautaire sur COVID-19 qui intègrent la prévention de la violence sexuelle et basée dur le genre; et 3) soutenir les établissements de santé et les communautés en leur fournissant des provisions essentielles en matière d'eau, d'assainissement et d'hygiène. Les activités liées à COVID-19 devraient bénéficier directement à 676 794 personnes (dont 380 949 femmes et filles), composées de travailleurs de la santé, d'agents de santé communautaires et d'autres agents communautaires.

This project aims to reduce maternal, neonatal and child mortality in select communities by working with local health authorities, and supporting the use of an integrated approach focused on health, nutrition, and water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH). The project is also providing additional funds in response to the immediate needs of the COVID-19 pandemic by training and supporting health care workers, reaching communities on critical health topics, and providing water, sanitation and hygiene supplies to health facilities and communities. The expected intermediate outcomes for this initiative include: (1) improved delivery of essential health services to mothers, pregnant women, newborns and children under five; (2) improved utilization of essential health services by mothers, pregnant women, newborns and children under five; and (3) increased consumption of nutritious foods and supplements by mothers, pregnant women, newborns and children under five.

title.narrative: Améliorer la santé des mères, des nouveau-nés et des enfants - Réponse au COVID-19
Enhancing Mother, Newborn and Child Health - Response to COVID-19

description.narrative: Ce projet vise à répondre à la menace du coronavirus (COVID-19) au Cambodge et aux Philippines en réduisant ou en prévenant la transmission locale de la COVID-19 et les effets disproportionnés de la COVID-19 sur les femmes et les filles au foyer, dans la communauté et sur le plan structurel. Les activités du projet comprennent : 1) fournir un soutien aux individus, en particulier aux femmes et aux filles, pour qu’ils puissent accéder et contrôler les ressources d’ordre pratique nécessaires à leur santé et à leur bien-être pendant la pandémie, comme les équipements de protection individuelle, le soutien psychosocial, les trousses de soutien alimentaire et financier, et le matériel d’hygiène menstruelle pour les personnes en quarantaine ou en isolement; 2) soutenir les ménages vulnérables qui ont perdu leurs moyens de subsistance, au moyen de conseils et d’une aide à la médiation pour prolonger les prêts et retarder les calendriers de remboursement ainsi que fournir du soutien pour contribuer à la continuité de l’agriculture et de la pêche, et offrir des transferts d’argent ciblés et/ou des trousses d’aide alimentaire nutritionnelle; 3) soutenir la continuité des services de santé vitaux, comme les services de santé et de protection des droits sexuels et génésiques et les services de lutte contre la violence sexiste, et les besoins en matière de soins familiaux; 4) sensibiliser le public, avec les partenaires locaux, aux questions liées à la COVID-19, à la santé sexuelle et génésique et à la violence sexiste au moyen de la radio, de matériel d’information, d’éducation et de communication, des médias sociaux, de l’envoi de SMS et de haut-parleurs; 5) renforcer la capacité des institutions à réduire la transmission et à répondre aux besoins particuliers des personnes touchées par la pandémie. Ce projet vise à toucher 106 535 personnes. Ce projet fournit également un soutien à la quarantaine frontalière, qui contribue à protéger une population totale estimée à 3 005 018 personnes.

This project works to respond to the threat of coronavirus (COVID-19) in Cambodia and the Philippines, by reducing or preventing local COVID-19 transmission and the disproportionate gender effects of COVID-19 on women and girls at the household, community, and structural level in Cambodia and the Philippines. Project activities include: (1) providing support to individuals, especially women and girls, to gain access and control over the practical resources necessary for their health and well-being during the pandemic, such as personal protective equipment, psychosocial support, food and financial support kits, and materials for menstrual hygiene for those in quarantine or isolation; (2) supporting vulnerable households who have lost their livelihoods, through counseling and mediation assistance to extend loans and delay repayment schedules, as well as provide supports to assist with continuity of farming and fishing, and provide targeted cash transfers and/or nutritional food assistance kits; (3) supporting the continuity of life saving health services, such as sexual reproductive health and rights and gender-based violence services and family care needs; (4) raising public awareness with local partners on matters related to COVID-19, sexual and reproductive health, and gender-based violence via radio, information education and communication materials, social media, SMS blasts and loudspeaker; and (5) building the capacity of institutions to reduce transmission and respond to the gender specific needs of those impacted by the pandemic. This project expects to reach 106,535 people. This project also provides border quarantine support, which contributes to protecting an estimated total population of 3,005,018 people.
